title: Senate suspends 'tokhang for ransom' probe
text:
Choi Kyung-jin, left, the widow of South Korean businessman Jee Ick-joo, who was kidnapped and later killed by his abductors, watches   Chief Ronald Dela Rosa, right, showing her househelp Marissa Morquicho documents at the start of the Philippine Senate probe in the killing Thursday, Jan. 26, 2017 in suburban Pasay city, south of Manila, Philippines. The killing of Jee prompted President Rodrigo Duterte to apologize to the South Korean government. Morquicho was kidnapped by abductors, who were later identified as active police officers, together with Jee but was released unharmed. AP/Bullit Marquez Patricia Lourdes Viray  32pm 
  Senate committee on public order and dangerous drugs suspended its inquiry into the various reported incidents of kidnap for ransom perpetrated by members of the   (PNP). 
Sen. Panfilo Lacson ordered the suspension of the "tokhang for ransom" probe following the order of PNP Director General Ronald "Bato" Dela Rosa to dissolve the PNP Anti-illegal Drugs Group. Related Stories Alvarez: Bato should resign to spare Duterte from embarrassment 
"In view of the massively restructured war against illegal drugs that has abolished all the PNP's anti-drugs units in order to focus on police scalawags as ordered by the president, it is my view that the Senate wait and see how this latest development plays out," Lacson said in a statement released Monday. 
The Senate panel was scheduled to continue the "tokhang for ransom" hearing on Thursday. 
Dela Rosa ordered to stop the drug war during   within police regional offices. 
Lacson said that the Senate panel, which he chairs, has partially achieved the purposes of legislative inquiry as President Rodrigo Duterte has taken a positive action on the matter. 
"It is now time to immediately attend to the pertinent legislative measures referred to the committee," the senator said. 
Dela Rosa earlier said that the "cleansing" among police ranks will be prioritized over the war on drugs following the so-called "tokhang for ransom" perpetrated by some police officers. 
The PNP chief has ordered operatives to look for Superintendent Rafael Dumlao III, a team leader of the PNP-AIDG, who is allegedly linked in the kidnap-slay case  Joo.
